content.rendered:
2 August

When he had finished washing their feet, he put on his clothes and returned to his place. ‘Do you understand what I have done for you?’ he asked them. 13 ‘You call me “Teacher” and “Lord”, and rightly so, for that is what I am. 14 Now that I, your Lord and Teacher, have washed your feet, you also should wash one another’s feet. 15 I have set you an example that you should do as I have done for you. 16 I tell you the truth, no servant is greater than his master, nor is a messenger greater than the one who sent him. 17 Now that you know these things, you will be blessed if you do them’ (John 13:12–17).

After the feet-washing, our Lord resumed his garments and sat down. He proceeded to explain to them what he had done, and why. Whether the once-for-all cleansing of regeneration (see verse 10) or the daily, oft-repeated forgiveness referred to in these verses, the washing was his sole prerogative. ‘Salvation is found in no-one else, for there is no other name under heaven given to men by which we must be saved’ (Acts 4:12).

What he does for us in our servant sphere we must do for others. This is the message he seeks to inculcate, and it is an exceedingly challenging one. If the Teacher and Master stoops to minister to the simplest needs of his servants, and becomes their Servant (‘I am among you as one who serves’, Luke 22:27), surely it is not too much to expect that his children will take pleasure in serving each other. How hardly learned is this lesson! So our Lord emphasises the point: I have set you an example, that you should do as I have done to you.

Consider further his challenge to obedience. Re-reading the final sentence of this passage (verse 16), one’s thoughts are directed not only to the Lord’s gracious command to us his disciples and servants, but also to his Father commanding him, for the Father is ‘the one who sent him’. The perfect submission of the equal Son to the Father is a wonderful relationship and it provides a paradigm which imposes absolute obligation on our Lord’s disciples. Though Christ was a man on earth, his status with the Father and his submission to him were the unanswerable argument for Christ’s followers’ perfect submission both to him and to each other.

This week’s devotionals are from Through the Year With William Still
